lg.l: Let's think of eggs
They have no legs
Chickens come from eggs,
But they have legs.
The plot thickens—
Eggs come from chickens
But have no legs under 'em:
What a conundrum!
The owl and the pussycat went to sea
In a beautiful pea-green boat
They took some money
And plenty of honey
Wrapped up in a five-pound note
The owl looked up at the stars above
And sang to a small guitar,
lg.note: Possibly a ukelele, though these were not common in England in Lear's time.
lg.l: O Lovely Pussy! O Pussy my love!
What a beautiful pussy you are
You are, you are,
What a beautiful pussy you are!
Pussy said to the owl,
You elegant fowl!
How marvellous sweet you sing!
O let us be married,
Too long we have tarried!
But what shall we do for a ring?
So they sailed away for a year and a day
To the land where the Bong-tree grows,
And there in a wood, a Piggy-wig stood
With a ring in the end of his nose,
His nose, his nose,
With a ring in the end of his nose.
O Pig, are you willing
To sell for one shilling
Your ring? Said the piggy, I will!
So they bore it away, and were married next day
By the turkey who lives on the hill.
They dined on quince, and plenty of mince,
Served up with a runcible spoon,
And hand in hand, by the edge of the sand,
They danced by the light of the moon—
The moon, the moon—
They danced by the light of the moon.
